subject: Economics
title: Negative Interest Rates: Paying Banks to Borrow
description: A fast breakdown of Negative Interest Rates: Paying Banks to Borrow for builders.

hook.text: In 2014, the European Central Bank did something once thought impossible: it charged banks for saving money.

buildup.text: Normally banks earn interest on deposits. Negative rates meant the ECB charged -0.5% â€” banks paid to park cash.

discovery.text: The logic: if saving costs money, banks will lend more aggressively. More loans mean more economic activity.

twist.text: Some Danish homeowners got mortgages that paid them interest. The bank paid you to borrow money.

climax.text: Negative rates broke a 5,000-year assumption: that lending money earns interest. The rules of money aren't permanent.

punchline.text: For a few years, banks literally paid people to borrow.

quiz.question: What was the purpose of negative interest rates?
options: Force banks to lend more by making it costly to hold deposits
